content: Why Bonds Fail Differently? Explainable Multimodal Learning for Multi-Class Default Prediction Link to working paper ‚Üó Authors: Yi Lu, Aifan Ling, Chaoqun Wang, Yaxin Xu Source: NEP-FOR (2025-09-13) Summary: The paper presents EMDLOT, a novel framework for multi-class bond default prediction that integrates numerical time-series data and unstructured textual data. It employs Time-Aware LSTM to manage irregular sequences and enhances interpretability through soft clustering and multi-level attention mechanisms. The framework demonstrates superior performance in predicting bond defaults compared to traditional and deep learning models, making it a practical tool for financial risk modeling and decision-making.
title: ets4: October 2025 Issue

content: Out-of-sample gravity predictions and trade policy counterfactuals Link to working paper ‚Üó Authors: Nicolas Apfel, Holger Breinlich, Nick Green, Dennis Novy, J. M. C. Santos Silva, Tom Zylkin Source: NEP-FOR (2025-09-13) Summary: This paper evaluates the out-of-sample predictive power of gravity equations used in trade policy analysis, comparing them with machine learning methods like random forests and neural networks. It finds that while the 3-way gravity model performs well on average, ensemble machine learning methods can outperform it for predicting individual bilateral trade flows. The focus on predictive performance and methodology suggests a strong relevance to forecasting economic time series, particularly in the context of trade flows.
title: ets4: October 2025 Issue

content: Stabilising Lifetime PD Models under Forecast Uncertainty Link to working paper ‚Üó Authors: Vahab Rostampour Source: NEP-FOR (2025-09-13) Summary: The paper addresses the challenge of estimating lifetime probabilities of default (PDs) under IFRS 9 and CECL by reformulating the forecasting problem within a state-space framework. It introduces an anchored observation model that incorporates a neutral long-run economic state, which stabilizes the PD term structure and reduces forecast noise. The empirical results from simulations indicate that this approach leads to smoother and more interpretable projections, highlighting its potential for improving economic forecasting in credit risk assessment.
title: ets4: October 2025 Issue

content: Meta-Learning Neural Process for Implied Volatility Surfaces with SABR-induced Priors Link to working paper ‚Üó Authors: Jirong Zhuang, Xuan Wu Source: NEP-FOR (2025-09-13) Summary: The paper presents a novel approach to constructing implied volatility surfaces (IVS) using a meta-learning framework, specifically through a Volatility Neural Process. This model is trained to reconstruct IVS from limited market quotes, significantly improving predictive accuracy over traditional methods like SABR and Gaussian Process. The results indicate a substantial reduction in RMSE, particularly in areas with sparse data, showcasing its potential for practical applications in financial forecasting.
title: ets4: October 2025 Issue

content: Financial Shocks and the Output Growth Distribution Link to working paper ‚Üó Authors: Francois-Michel Boire, Thibaut Duprey, Alexander Ueberfeldt Source: NEP-FOR (2025-09-13) Summary: This paper introduces a quantile-augmented vector autoregression (QAVAR) model that integrates quantile regressions into a structural VAR framework, allowing for flexible, nonparametric forecasts of conditional moments and tail risk measures for GDP. The findings reveal that adverse financial shocks significantly increase downside risk to GDP growth, highlighting the model‚Äôs capability to capture nonlinearities and heterogeneous tail dynamics in economic forecasting. The QAVAR model‚Äôs innovative approach to forecasting tail risks and conditional moments makes it a valuable tool for predicting economic outcomes under financial stress.

content: The ECB-Multi Country Model. A semi-structural model for forecasting and policy analysis for the largest euro area countries Link to working paper ‚Üó Authors: Angelini, Elena, Bokan, Nikola, Ciccarelli, Matteo, Lalik, Magdalena, Zimic, Sreƒçko Source: NEP-FOR (2025-09-13) Summary: The paper presents the European Central Bank‚Äôs Multi Country model (ECB-MC), which is designed for economic forecasting and policy analysis for major euro area economies. It emphasizes the model‚Äôs ability to conduct scenario, risk, and sensitivity analyses, thereby providing a structured approach to forecasting economic dynamics. The ECB-MC serves as a reference for macroeconomic projections, highlighting its practical applications in understanding the effects of economic shocks.

content: Assessing Asymmetric Macroeconomic Risk Link to working paper ‚Üó Authors: St√©phane Lhuissier Source: NEP-FOR (2025-10-13) Summary: The paper introduces a dynamic factor model with time-varying skewness to assess asymmetric macroeconomic risk, specifically focusing on the predictive capabilities of macroeconomic aggregates. It demonstrates that the model enhances the detection of downside risks to growth and provides more accurate predictive distributions, particularly during economic downturns. The findings suggest that utilizing a richer information set can significantly improve economic forecasting accuracy.

content: Adaptive Temporal Fusion Transformers for Cryptocurrency Price Prediction Link to working paper ‚Üó Authors: Arash Peik, Mohammad Ali Zare Chahooki, Amin Milani Fard, Mehdi Agha Sarram Source: NEP-FOR (2025-09-13) Summary: This paper presents an adaptive Temporal Fusion Transformer (TFT) approach for short-term cryptocurrency price prediction, addressing the challenges posed by market volatility and non-stationarity. The authors introduce a novel segmentation method that captures significant upward price movements, allowing for more responsive forecasting. Experimental results indicate that this adaptive model outperforms traditional fixed-length TFT and LSTM models in terms of prediction accuracy and trading profitability, showcasing its potential for practical applications in trading strategies. Reason for Interest: The adaptive segmentation and pattern-based forecasting methods could be applied to economic time series, such as stock prices or commodity prices, to enhance prediction accuracy in volatile markets.

content: ¬†The paper Comparing predictive ability in presence of instability over a very short time, co-authored with my former Ph.D. advisors Fabrizio Iacone and Luca Rossini, is now published in The Econometrics Journal. Abstract We consider forecast comparison in the presence of instability when this affects only a short period of time. We demonstrate that global tests do not perform well in this case, as they were not designed to capture very short-lived instabilities, and their power vanishes altogether when the magnitude of the shock is very large. We then propose and discuss approaches that are more suitable to detect such situations, such as nonparametric methods like the S test from Andrews (2003) or the MAX procedure from Harvey et al. (2021). We illustrate these results in a Monte Carlo exercise and in a comparison of the nowcast of the quarterly US nominal GDP from the Survey of Professional Forecasters (SPF) against a naive benchmark of no growth, over a period that includes the GDP instability brought by the COVID-19 crisis. We recommend that the forecaster does not pool the sample, but excludes the short periods of high local instability from the evaluation exercise. Motivation Predictive ability tests can be misleading in the presence of short and deep shocks. To see why, consider the nowcasts for U.S. Nominal GDP growth from the Survey of Professional Forecasters (SPF) versus a na√Øve, zero-growth benchmark. Figure 1: U.S. nominal GDP growth (black dotted line), GDP nowcast from the SPF (blue line), and na√Øve nowcast (red line) over the period 2000:Q1 to 2020:Q3. As the figure and RMSE metrics in the table below suggest, the SPF is more accurate than the na√Øve benchmark, even during the COVID-19 crisis. Surprisingly, however, predictive ability tests like the Diebold-Mariano and Fluctuation tests fail to find any significant difference between the two forecasts. Table 1: RMSE_SPF and RMSE_Na√Øve are the average RMSE for the SPF and na√Øve benchmark, respectively. Ratio refers to the ratio RMSE_SPF/RMSE_Na√Øve. DM, Fl_l, and Fl_u are the Diebold and Mariano (1995), and lower and upper Fluctuation test (Giacomini and Rossi, 2010) statistics. The 5% critical values for two-sided tests are 2.032 (fixed smoothing) and 3.012, respectively. Period RMSE_SPF RMSE_Naive Ratio DM Fl_l Fl_u Q1:2000 ‚Äî Q4:2019 0.37 1.66 0.22 -7.27 -5.83 -2.04 Q1:2000 ‚Äî Q3:2020 0.59 3.77 0.16 -1.92 -2.49 -0.21 In the paper, we show this happens because the power of tests like Diebold-Mariano or the Fluctuation test vanishes when instability is very short-lived, even if the shock is very large. Consequently, forecasters pooling data might wrongly conclude that their forecasts are not more accurate than a na√Øve benchmark. To address this issue, we propose using tests better suited for detecting short-lived instabilities, such as the S test from Andrews (2003) or the MAX procedure from Harvey et al. (2021). These tests are designed to capture local instabilities and have power in these situations. Replication package All replication files are available in my GitHub repository, where you can find implementations of the predictive ability tests discussed in the paper, including: Diebold and Mariano (1995) Fluctuation (Giacomini & Rossi, 2010) S (Andrews, 2003) MAX (Harvey et al., 2021) Running the main files will reproduce all results. We use the S and MAX tests specifically to assess predictive ability over very short periods. Please consult the README for complete details.
title: Insight: Comparing predictive ability in presence of instability over a very short time

content: I am a postdoctoral researcher in the Department of Economics, Management, and Quantitative Methods at the University of Milan. I hold a PhD in Economics from the University of Milan and University of Pavia, awarded in February 2025. My research interests include forecast evaluation, forecasting methods, and causal inference in macro/energy. Some of my specific areas of focus are: Forecast evaluation: Considering tests with alternative loss functions, evaluating performance in the presence of weak signal, and reviewing applied studies. Forecast combinations: Developing classical and Bayesian techniques to combine a diverse set of forecasts/forecasting methods. Causal inference: Using structural models to analyze energy markets and their connections with the macroeconomy, with a strong emphasis on policy. Probabilistic programming: Exploring its application for modern time series analysis, forecasting, and causal inference. Alternative data: Leveraging text data and other novel data sources for forecasting and risk measurement. I am always open to exploring interesting and challenging research questions, particularly those with a vision and strong technological potential. Feel free to contact me at viselliandrea@gmail.com. My curriculum vitae is available here.

content: IT-Nowcast A monthly real-time forecast of the Italian (2020 chain-linked) Gross Domestic Product (GDP) We provide monthly nowcasts and backcasts for quarter-on-quarter (QoQ) GDP growth. The backcasts revise the nowcast for the previous month. Additionally, we offer quarterly nowcasts for the level of GDP and the associated error for the GDP growth nowcast. Monthly updates occur at the end of each month, while quarterly updates are provided at the end of each quarter. Further details on the methodology and the historical nowcast series are available at the end of the page. Quarterly nowcast (Last Update: July 22, 2025) Figure 1: Italian QoQ GDP growth nowcasts and realizations in 2020 chain linked values. Notice that, prior to the latest nowcast, we display pseudo real time nowcasts. The empirical prediction intervals are computed using the history of the nowcast errors (zoom the chart for more details). QoQ % Change (back) QoQ % Change (now) 5% Pr. (now) 95% Pr. (now) 0.13 0.20 -0.11 0.62 Table 1: Monthly nowcast and empirical prediction intervals at the 5% and 95% level for the QoQ GDP growth rate (see Figure 1). Reference quarter nowcast (Last Update: Q2-2025) Figure 2: Italian quarterly GDP level nowcasts and realizations in 2020 chain linked values and in thousands of millions of euros. Notice that, prior to the latest nowcast, we display pseudo real time nowcasts (zoom the chart for more details). QoQ % Change YoY % Change Carry Over Level 0.20 0.67 0.46 486.15 Table 2: Nowcasted QoQ and YoY growth rates, carry-over annual effect, and level for GDP (see Figure 2). Notice that the carry-over annual effect is not available on the first quarter of the year, whereas it coincides with the YoY % Change for the last quarter of the year. Figure 3: Italian QoQ GDP growth nowcast errors in 2020 chain linked values. The latest available figure is relative to Q1:2025. Notice that, prior to the latest nowcast, we display pseudo real time nowcasts (zoom the chart for more details). Methodological note Nowcasting methods aim to provide the general public -‚Äî such as policymakers, media, and investors -‚Äî with real-time assessments of critical economic indicators that would otherwise be subject to significant publication delays. In brief, these methods leverage higher-frequency data to forecast indicators that are released less frequently. For example, the quarterly Italian GDP figure is published approximately one and a half months after the reference quarter. This means e.g. the Q1 figure (covering January, February, and March) is only released in mid-April; however, industrial production, which shows a strong correlation with GDP, is released monthly and can be used to nowcast GDxP. The econometric methodology used in this report is based on the working paper, Nowcast Combinations in Presence of Instabilities, A. Viselli (2024), which has not yet been disseminated. The code will soon be made publicly available on GitHub. Historical nowcasts UPDATES ARE CURRENTLY SUSPENDED DUE TO IN-PROGRESS IMPROVEMENTS TO THE METHODOLOGY AND PIPELINE. Click here to download the historical nowcast series. Notice that the nowcasts prior to October 2024 are not provided as they are derived from an out-of-sample exercise. Viselli (2024).
